title: A Startup Gets Money to Build Big Satellites
summary: A company called K2 has raised $250 million to build large satellites in California. K2 makes two types: Mega and Giga satellites. Their first big satellite, named Gravitas, will launch in 2026 on a Falcon 9 rocket. Gravitas will test powerful thrusters and solar arrays. The US Space Force is helping pay for this mission. K2 plans to use big rockets like Starship to send Giga satellites into space. These satellites can make a lot of power for tasks like AI and telescopes. K2 builds many parts itself to save money and make more satellites. The goal is to explore new things in space.

keywords.explanation: machines that orbit Earth and do jobs in space
a device that pushes a satellite to move in space
panels that catch sunlight to make electricity for satellites
vehicles that launch satellites into space
a building where things like satellites are made

questions.question: What is the name of the startup that raised $250 million?
What are the two types of satellites K2 is building?
When is Gravitas scheduled to launch?
Who is funding the Gravitas demo mission?

background_read: Satellites are machines that go around Earth to help with things like communication, weather tracking, and science. Companies build them in factories and use rockets to send them into space. Some satellites are small, but K2 is making big ones to do more powerful jobs. Rockets like Falcon 9 and Starship can carry heavy loads. The US Space Force is part of the military that works on space projects. This article talks about how K2 got money to build and test new big satellites.
Article_Structure: WHO: K2, a startup company, and its founders like Karan Kunjur.
WHAT: Building Mega and Giga satellites, with Gravitas as the first demo.
WHERE: Torrance, California, and in orbit around Earth.
WHY: To explore new possibilities in space and support missions like AI and telescopes.

perspectives.description: K2 is creating big satellites to do new things in orbit, like powering AI and telescopes.
